H0.text: Cell is what has functions that are reflected by the variety of cell shapes seen in prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

H1.text: Proteins reflect the functions that each variety of cell shape seen in prokaryotes and eukaryotes has.

H2.text: Life has functions that the variety of cell shapes seen in prokaryotes and eukaryotes reflects.

H3.text: Organ reflects the functions that each variety of cell shape seen in prokaryotes and eukaryotes has.

A4.text: The cytoskeleton provides the capability for movement within the cell.

A5.text: This causes prokaryotes to have a larger surface‑area‑to‑volume ratio, giving them a higher metabolic rate, a higher growth rate, and as a consequence, a shorter generation time than eukaryotes.

A6.text: Cell biology encompasses both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, with subtopics including the study of cell metabolism, cell communication, cell cycle, biochemistry, and cell composition.

A7.text: Cell culture is one of the major tools used in cellular and molecular biology, providing excellent model systems for studying the normal physiology and biochemistry of cells (e.g., metabolic studies, aging), the effects of drugs and toxic compounds on the cells, and mutagenesis and carcinogenesis.
